problems.title: AI Music Generation Copyright and Authorship Uncertainty
problems.description: The rapid advancement of AI music generation tools like Suno and Udio has created fundamental uncertainty around copyright ownership, licensing obligations, and authorship rights. AI models trained on copyrighted music without permission or compensation raise serious legal and ethical questions. The music industry argues that 'ingestion without permission is theft,' while AI companies claim fair use protections. This has resulted in multiple lawsuits, with Universal Music Group and Warner Music Group reaching settlements with Udio and Suno in late 2025. The lack of clear legal frameworks means artists cannot definitively know if their work was used to train AI systems, and the ownership of AI-generated music remains legally ambiguous. This uncertainty threatens both human creators who may be displaced and the integrity of music rights systems built over decades.

problems.title: Streaming Royalty Inequity for Independent and Emerging Artists
problems.description: The current streaming royalty model creates severe economic disparities between major label artists and independent or emerging musicians. With per-stream payouts averaging $0.003-0.005, artists need millions of streams to earn meaningful income. The pro-rata payment model, where all subscription revenue is pooled and distributed based on total stream share, heavily favors already-popular artists and major labels. Independent artists often earn less than minimum wage equivalent for their music despite significant listener engagement. This structural inequity makes it nearly impossible for most musicians to sustain careers solely through streaming revenue, forcing them to rely on touring, merchandise, or outside employment. The problem is compounded by the power imbalance in negotiations, where streaming platforms can dictate terms to artists with limited leverage.

problems.title: Artist Mental Health Crisis and Creative Burnout Epidemic
problems.description: Musicians experience depression at rates up to three times higher than the general population, with over 73% of independent music makers reporting symptoms of mental illness. The music industry faces a systemic mental health crisis driven by financial instability, grueling touring schedules, social media pressure, and a culture that normalizes anxiety, burnout, and addiction. Artists face constant pressure to create, promote, and maintain visibility online while managing irregular income and lack of job security. The industry has historically invested heavily in branding and marketing while neglecting artist wellbeing and emotional resilience. Organizations like Backline and Amber Health have emerged to address the crisis, with services being brought on major tours, but support remains fragmented and inaccessible to most artists. Calls for an industry-wide Code of Practice around mental health are growing, but implementation remains slow.

problems.title: Live Music Ticket Affordability and Fan Accessibility Crisis
problems.description: Concert ticket prices have reached all-time highs, with significant increases since 2019 pricing out many fans from live music experiences. Dynamic pricing, service fees that can add 30-50% to ticket costs, and ticket scalping have made attending concerts increasingly unaffordable for average consumers. The Live Nation-Ticketmaster monopoly faces antitrust lawsuits from the FTC and Department of Justice over market control and pricing practices. Despite claims of a 'historic year for live music,' Live Nation reported an 11% drop in Q1 2025 earnings including a 14% dip in concert revenue and 4% decline in ticketing, suggesting price elasticity limits are being reached. This affordability crisis threatens the long-term sustainability of live music by alienating younger and lower-income fans who cannot develop concert-going habits.

problems.title: Music Discovery Algorithm Bias Against Emerging Artists
problems.description: Major streaming platforms' recommendation algorithms systematically favor established artists and familiar sounds over emerging talent, creating a discovery barrier for new musicians. Platforms like Spotify have come under fire for algorithmic bias that optimizes for engagement metrics rather than musical exploration, resulting in a 'rich get richer' dynamic. As one industry voice notes, 'Authentic discovery occurs when tastemakers take risks and surface music before the data confirms it is safe.' The shift away from human curation toward algorithmic recommendations has reduced serendipitous discovery. This creates a challenging environment for breaking new artists who cannot gain algorithmic visibility without existing popularity, trapping them in an exposure paradox. The problem affects both artists struggling to build audiences and fans missing out on music they would enjoy.

problems.title: Rising Touring Costs Threatening Mid-Tier Artist Viability
problems.description: The economics of touring have become increasingly unsustainable, particularly for mid-tier artists. Production costs, transportation, accommodation, crew wages, and visa expenses have escalated dramatically, with US visa costs nearly quadrupling in recent years. The pandemic's aftershocks continue to reverberate through higher insurance costs and supply chain disruptions. While touring was traditionally how artists compensated for low streaming revenue, rising costs are squeezing margins to the point where many tours are financially unviable. International touring has become especially challenging due to visa restrictions and cross-border logistics. This threatens the ability of developing artists to build audiences through live performance, which remains the most effective way to convert casual listeners into dedicated fans.

problems.title: Artificial Streaming and Bot Farm Manipulation
problems.description: Bot farms generating artificial streams pose a persistent threat to legitimate artists and the integrity of streaming platform economics. Fraudulent streaming operations inflate play counts for certain tracks, distorting royalty distributions and chart positions. This diverts revenue from genuine artists to fraudulent operations and undermines trust in streaming metrics as indicators of actual popularity. While major DSPs have invested heavily in detection and prevention technology throughout 2025, the battle continues as fraud operations evolve to evade detection. The problem affects legitimate artists who lose revenue share, labels investing based on manipulated data, and platforms whose credibility depends on accurate metrics. Industry estimates suggest billions of fraudulent streams occur annually, representing significant misdirected royalties.

Independent artists face fewer truly independent options for distribution, publishing, and services, potentially forcing them into major label ecosystems regardless of their preferences.

problems.title: AI-Generated Content Threatening Human Creator Market Value
problems.description: The proliferation of AI-generated music threatens to flood streaming platforms with synthetic content, potentially devaluing human-created music. AI tools can now generate unlimited quantities of music at near-zero marginal cost, raising concerns about market saturation and the economic viability of human music creators. With streaming royalty pools divided by total plays, an influx of AI content could dilute payments to human artists even further. The industry is grappling with how to differentiate human and AI content, whether AI music should receive the same royalty treatment, and how to preserve space for human creativity in an AI-saturated market.

The emphasis on short-form viral content may be changing how music is created, favoring hook-driven snippets over cohesive artistic works.
